subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove, and I’d like to talk today about the psychology of
enlightenment. Enlightenment means many different things to many different people.
In the yoga
tradition, in the tradition of Hinduism, enlightenment means achieving
total bliss, total union with god,
complete awareness with everything
at one. You could call it cosmic consciousness. It's a sustained
awareness. One becomes, as an enlightened being, an avatar, a
representative of the highest deity here on Earth.
Not just a
representative, it's not even strong enough a word, but an exemplar, a
part of God. In the Buddhist tradition,
enlightenment is a bit different than the Hindu because
the ideal of Buddhism is nirvana,
which you might say is almost the opposite of the Hindu version, yet somehow the same.
Nothingness, pure nothingness, pure indifference. The Buddhists say it doesn't matter if I’m alive or dead,
I’m indifferent to that, I’m detached.
Detachment is often spoken of in the Hindu tradition as well,
so it gets very confusing. Scholars have debated about this for
aeons, for millennia. There are, you know, 1,000 books about
enlightenment. What is it really? Well, the Freudians viewed it as a regression to an
infantile state. People who claimed one with everything,
unity with God, total bliss, or even total detachment,
were thought of as simply regressing to a state where they are back in the womb, or maybe just born,
suckling at their mothers breast.
It was not considered an advanced state until the work of the great psychologist Abraham
Maslow.
Maslow began studying the most creative people of his era: Einstein,
Eleanor Roosevelt, Hellen Keller, he began looking at their accomplishments
to find out how is it in the Western context that people of great accomplishments achieved
their vision, or as he would say, actualize themselves -
actualized themselves. He discovered in interviewing these people that they all
reported what he called peak
experiences. Furthermore, these peak experiences were pretty much indistinguishable from the
experiences reported by the great
yogis and mystics of our culture: cosmic consciousness, the sense of oneness, a
total sense of unity, of purpose, of
commitment, of doing things in the world,
and knowing with great certainty, from the depths of your being, that you’re doing the right thing.
Many people report
states on enlightenment that hit them quite suddenly.
For a long time
I studied the teachings of a man known as Meher Baba, who is considered by his followers, and still is, an
avatar, in sort of a Sufi-Hindu kind of milieu. He was actually, I think Persian. But in any case,
he became enlightened one day when he was passing by a
guru, a Sufi master. The Sufi master grabbed a stone and threw it at him and hit him smack right in the forehead.
Boom, he was enlightened from that moment on. He knew himself to be an avatar.
A god on earth, in his view. Other people -
there was a very popular leader of the human potential movement and growth groups back in the
who called themselves Werner Erhard. He claimed to have achieved a state of cosmic consciousness
while flying his airplane. He had a small airplane,
and he was flying along in the clouds, and all of a sudden it dawned on him - boom! pop! - and he was enlightened.
Yet, one can find in so many of these stories of the great gurus and the great teachers that they often have
what are called “feet of clay.” They may be enlightened in some regards but in other regards they are very, very
human - all too human,
one might say. Particularly, we are talking about sexual peccadilloes or financial
misbehaviour. So, I think it's fair to say you can be
enlightened in some respects and not enlightened in others. Take the Buddha, for example. Historically,
I think, all followers of traditions that speak of enlightenment would hold
Gautama Buddha in high regard. And
yet, there is a story told, as I recall, by his cousin, who was his scribe, Ananda. It
happened one day -
these are believed to be true stories from the direct witnesses involved -
Ananda reported that there were monks
in the Buddhist order. That’s what they were, they were monks. But, there were many women followers
who were not allowed to become monks in the early days of the Buddhist sangha, or community.
Ananda told him, “The women are complaining. Can’t they also become monks?” The Buddha said, “All right.
We’ll set up an order for Buddhist females monks.
But, it's a real shame, for if we only had male monks, our
Buddhist community would last a thousand years. But, now that we’re taking in females, our community will only last
500 years or so.” Now we know, over
2,000 years later, he was wrong on all counts.
So, was he enlightened in every single respect? Of course not.
That's how I view
enlightenment, I guess. You sort of have to look at it
bit by bit,
aspect by aspect, compartment by compartment.
The human psyche has many different compartments, many different mansions
exist within my father’s house, you might say. Well,
I’m Jewish as I’ve pointed out in the previous segment, quite extensively. There's a tradition in Judaism that
one can never see the face of God, let alone merge with God and live.
The human body just can't tolerate it. Moses, the greatest of all the Hebrew prophets, traditionally, but not in my book -
Moses apparently, according to legend, saw the face of God right before he died.
That suggests that those who claim absolute, ultimate God-like status...
Well, from a Jewsish perspective, there's every reason to be skeptical,
every reason to be sskeptical. There have been some in
Judaism who claimed to be a messiah-like figure, and usually it ended very badly.
There are many, many examples of people who
claimed to have achieved that kind of height of enlightenment. As the old saying goes,
pride goeth before the fall.
So, those whom the gods would destroy they first fill with pride.
Now, what about you?
Where do you think you are most enlightened, and where not? In the Western
sense, in the 18th century,
we called that the Age of Enlightenment. What is meant by that is if you’re enlightened, in the Western sense,
you're a rational person, you understand
Newtonian physics, you
don't believe in the divine right of kings, you believe in democracy, you believe in universal education.
That's a sense of enlightenment.
For feminists, enlightenment means that you
understand how you've been raised in a patriarchal society
that disparages women and denies them equal rights. If
you are oppressed in any sense, if you belong to a minority group that is oppressed by your oppressors, throwing off the
ideology of your oppressors and
recognizing yourself as a whole human being,
sufficient unto yourself, is a form of enlightenment.
Abraham Maslow, in his book, Toward a Psychology of Being, distinguished between the
psychology of being, the psychology of wholeness where you are
self contained in a positive way because you contribute to the lives of others, rather than being dependent. And
especially, rather than having what the Freudian Karen Horney
called neurotic needs, things you think you need, but really you don't.
That's the example of neurosis. And yet, one can find
what is sometimes called spiritual bypasses, people who can live in an ashram or spiritual community
and it seems as if they’re perfectly enlightened, but when they get out into the real world for one reason or another, the
psychological issues that they never addressed properly come up to the fore.
There's so much more that could be said about enlightenment because of course a thousand books have been written on the subject.
But, since I only have a few minutes let me leave you with this thought. One day,
in 1985 Christmas Eve,
I received a phone call from Ted Owens, the PK Man, whom I had been studying
for about 10 years at that time, who compared himself to Moses in terms of his great psycho-
kinetic and prophetic powers. He called me up and he said, “Jeffrey,” in his deep, booming voice,
“This is the most important phone call you will ever receive.”
Then he went on to tell me it was up to me to warn the U.S. government not to launch the next space shuttle because
the UFOs that he worked with had planned to knock it out of the sky. I,
of course, did nothing. But, I bring this story up not to
talk about Ted Owens and his powers or his claims to some sort of spiritual authority,
but to ask you to reflect on what if you were to receive a phone call:
“This is the most important phone call you will ever receive.
This is the phone call that will enable you to achieve a new level of enlightenment.
This is a message coming to you. Now, what would it be?”
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you for being with me.
